column1: Name#Sport#Years#Accomplishments

Ruth Alexander#Administrator#1972–81#Ruth Alexander was the driving force behind the founding of the Florida Gators women's sports program. As a physical education professor and associate athletic director
column2: she assumed responsibility for the rapid expansion of the Florida Gators women's sports program during the 1970s.

column1: Charles W. Bachman
column2: Jr.#Football#1928–32#Charlie Bachman was the head coach of the 1928 Florida Gators football team that produced a new national scoring record and the best win-loss record in the first eighty-nine years of Gators football.

column1: Percy M. Beard#Track & field#1937–64#Percy Beard was an Olympic silver medalist in the 120-meter hurdles in the 1932 Olympics. He became the head coach of the Floria Gators track and field team in 1937 and let the team for twenty-eight seasons
column2: including two SEC team championships.

column1: B. E. "Buster" Bishop#Men's golf#1964–78#Buster Bishop was the head coach of the Florida Gators men's golf team for fifteen years. During his tenure
column2: the Gators men's golfers won four SEC team championships and two NCAA national team championships—including the 1968 NCAA national team championship—the first national team championship

column1: Otis Boggs#Broadcasting##
Andy Brandi#Women's tennis#1984–2001#Andy Brandi was the head coach of the Florida Gators women's tennis team for seventeen years. During his tenure
column2: the Lady Gators won fourteen SEC team championships
column3: and three NCAA national team championships
column4: in addition to finishing as the national runners-up in five other NCAA tournaments.

column1: J. Robert Cade#Sports medicine#1961–2004#Robert Cade was a professor of nephrology at the University of Florida College of Medicine. During the 1960s
column2: he and his research team conducted experiments with Florida Gators football players regarding water and electrolyte loss during athletic competition.

column1: Norman G. Carlson#Sports Information Director#1963–2011#Norm Carlson is a University of Florida alumnus and former sports journalist who was the sports information director of the Florida Gators sports program from 1963 to 2002.
Jimmy Carnes#Track & field#1965–76#Jimmy Carnes was the head coach of the Florida Gators track and field team
column2: with 93–3 record in dual meets. Carnes was also the founder of the Florida Track Club
column3: founder of the Sunshine State Games

column1: George Edmondson#Football mascot#1949–2008#"George Edmondson
column2: more commonly known as Mr. Two Bits
column3: served as an unofficial mascot and cheerleader at Florida Gators football games played at Florida Field for almost sixty years."

column1: Eugene Ellenson#Football
column2: Administrator#1960–69#Gene Ellenson was an assistant coach and the defensive coordinator of the Florida Gators football team from 1960 to 1969. He was revered by his players for his pregame motivational speeches.

column1: Dave Fuller#Baseball#1947–76#Dave Fuller was the head coach of the Florida Gators baseball team for thirty years
column2: and the longest serving coach in the history of the Florida Gators intercollegiate sports program.

column1: Frank Genovar#Swimming Tennis#1930–51 1941#Frank Genovar was the first head coach of the Florida Gators swimming and diving team
column2: and served in that role for twenty-two years.

column1: S. Ray Graves#Football
column2: Athletic Director#1960–69 1960–79#Ray Graves was the head coach of the Florida Gators football team from 1960 to 1969. He coached the Gators to their first two major bowl appearances
column3: compiled a 4–1 record in bowl games
column4: and an overall win-loss record of 70–31–4.

column1: Ben Hill Griffin
column2: Jr.#Financial contributor##Ben Hill Griffin
column3: Jr. was a University of Florida alumnus and namesake of the university's football facility

column1: Ben Hill Griffin
column2: III#Financial contributor##Ben Hill Griffin
column3: Jr. was a University of Florida alumnus and a generous contributor to the Florida Gators sports program.

column1: Spessard L. Holland#Supporter##Spessard Holland was an alumnus of the University of Florida College of Law. Holland was one of the founders of the law firm that became Holland & Knight
column2: and was later elected governor of the state (1941–45) and a U.S.

column1: Daniel T. McCarty#Supporter##Dan McCarty was a University of Florida alumnus and decorated U.S. Army officer in World War II.
Alfred A. McKethan#Financial contributor##Alfred McKethan was a University of Florida alumnus
column2: citrus grower
column3: cattleman and banker who served as the president of a small county bank that would become SunTrust Bank.

column1: J. Hillis Miller
column2: Sr.#President#1947–53#J. Hillis Miller served as the fourth president of the University of Florida for six years in the late 1940s and early 1950s.

column1: Bill Potter#Men's tennis#1952–77#Bill Potter was the head coach of the Florida Gators men's tennis team for twenty-six seasons. During Potter's tenure
column2: the Gators won four SEC team championships.

column1: Randy Reese#Swimming#1976–90#Randy Reese was the head coach of the Florida Gators swimming and diving teams for fifteen years. During his tenure
column2: the Gators men's and women's swimmers and divers won a combined seventeen SEC team championships

column1: Mimi Ryan#Women's golf#1973–94#Mimi Ryan was the first coach of the Florida Gators women's golf team. During her twenty-one years as head coach
column2: Ryan's Lady Gators won six SEC team championships
column3: and back-to-back NCAA national team championships in 1985 and 1986.

column1: Harold L. "Tom" Sebring#Football#1925–27#Tom Sebring was a law student who served as the head coach of the Gators football team for three seasons in the mid-1920s.
George Steinbrenner#Financial contributor##George Steinbrenner was the principal owner of the New York Yankees
column2: and several Tampa and Great Lakes-based shipping concerns. Steinbrenner was also a generous financial contributor to the Florida Gators sports program
column3: and he and his wife donated the funds to build the Steinbrenner Band Hall.

column1: G. A. "Pat" Summerall#Supporter##Placekicker Pat Summerall was a native of Lake City
column2: Florida
column3: and a ten-season veteran of the NFL before he became a national broadcaster for CBS Sports and Fox Sports.

column1: John J. Tigert
column2: IV#President#1928–47#John Tigert was the third president of the University of Florida
column3: and a strong advocate of intercollegiate sports. As a Vanderbilt undergraduate
column4: he was an All-Southern halfback and a Rhodes Scholar.

column1: James A. Van Fleet#Football#1923–24#James Van Fleet was a U.S. Army major and professor of military science in the university's ROTC program when he became the head coach of the Florida Gators football team.
Alfred C. Warrington
column2: IV#Financial contributor##Alfred Warrington is a major financial contributor to the Florida Gators sports program
column3: and the University of Florida generally. He is the namesake of the university's Warrington College of Business Administration
column4: and previously served as chairman of the university's board of trustees.

column1: Ernestine Weaver#Women's gymnastics#1980–92#Ernestine Weaver served as the head coach of the Florida Gators women's gymnastics team for twelve formative seasons. Her Lady Gators gymnasts were perennial conference and national contenders
column2: won six SEC team championships and the 1982 AIAW national team championship
column3: and made eleven consecutive appearances at the NCAA national championship tournament.

column1: G. Robert Woodruff#Football
column2: Athletic Director#1950–59#Bob Woodruff served as the head coach of the Florida Gators football team and the athletic director of the Florida Gators sports program.

column1: Everett M. Yon#Athletic Director
column2: Administrator#1925–28 1950–66#Everett Yon played for the Florida Gators football team in 1914 and 1915
